comments.body:
The common Ansible standard seems to be "yes" and "no" for booleans, but it looks like the recommendation for YAML 1.2 will be a limitation to "true" and "false" (presumably to be closer to JSON): https://yaml.org/spec/1.2/spec.html#id2804923 and https://yaml.org/spec/1.2/spec.html#id2803629

In light of that, does it make sense to insist on "yes" and "no"?
I'm not saying this must be changed, as I'm sure that Ansible will keep supporting those values even if moving to YAML 1.2 at some point. Just a general point.
I was always surprised to see this `yes/true` flag value that could cause some sort of confusion in how to set boolean flag. Happy to see that it's moving to a clearer definition.

I made these changes for consistency with the Ansible standard and doc_fragments. It will also be less confusing if it's `yes/no` for all modules.
But you're right, it perhaps doesn't make sense.
values in choices and default for bool should be `yes/no` according doc of ansible. it is a convention by Ansible. `required` should be true/false as it is a flag to show it is required.
Thanks for the clarification, @resmo . I suspected there was a guideline for that.
